study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the regulatory effects of Pterostilbene (PTE) on cell survival, drug resistance, and invasion in SUN-resistant renal cell carcinoma (RCC) cells.
results_summary: PTE induced apoptosis by upregulating the Bax/Bcl-2 ratio, increased SUN sensitivity by inhibiting RLIP76, reduced cell invasion, and downregulated MMP expression. It also suppressed the Ras/ERK and Akt/mTOR pathways.
population_specificity: SUN-resistant 786-O renal cell carcinoma cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene (PTE) improves sleep restriction-induced metabolic disorders and its relationship with the circadian clock.
results_summary: PTE significantly improved glucose and lipid metabolism, enhanced circadian behavior, and restored the circadian rhythm of liver clock and metabolic output genes in sleep-restricted mice. Molecular docking suggested PTE interacts with RORγ, potentially modulating Bmal1 transcription to maintain metabolic rhythm.
population_specificity: Male C57/B6J mice subjected to sleep restriction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene (PTE) could mitigate obesity-induced depression (OID) in mice by addressing insulin resistance, neuroinflammation, and hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis dysfunction.
results_summary: PTE-treated mice showed reduced body weight, depression-like behavior, and improved metabolic markers (insulin resistance, lipid profile, antioxidant enzymes, inflammatory cytokines). PTE also restored brain and adipose tissue architecture and upregulated SIRT1-mediated leptin-ghrelin signaling.
population_specificity: Adolescent Swiss albino male mice fed a cafeteria diet (CD) to induce obesity and depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-myeloma activity and immunomodulatory effects of DCZ0825, a derivative of pterostilbene, in multiple myeloma (MM) cells.
results_summary: DCZ0825 demonstrated direct anti-myeloma activity by inducing apoptosis and cell cycle arrest in MM cells, while also reversing immunosuppression by promoting M1 macrophage transformation and enhancing immune cell activity. It increased positive regulatory cells (CD4T, CD8T, NK cells) and decreased negative regulatory cells (Treg, MDSCs).
population_specificity: Multiple myeloma (MM) cells and associated immune cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer effects of PTER-ITC on human osteosarcoma MG-63 cells, focusing on its ability to inhibit survival, proliferation, and migration, and its underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: PTER-ITC inhibited osteosarcoma cell survival, proliferation, and migration, induced apoptosis, and reversed epithelial-mesenchymal transition by modulating key proteins and disrupting the β-catenin/TCF-4 interaction.
population_specificity: Human osteosarcoma MG-63 cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene (PTS) regulates Nrf2 in diabetic wounds and triggers a pro-wound healing response mediated by macrophages.
results_summary: PTS attenuated fibroblast migration, α-SMA, and HIF1α levels, rescued impaired wound closure in diabetic mice, and improved inflammatory markers and Nrf2 response, comparable to the standard treatment Regranex.
population_specificity: Diabetic mice with impaired wound healing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to design and synthesize novel pterostilbene derivatives with high anti-inflammatory activity and low toxicity, and evaluate their efficacy in treating acute colitis.
results_summary: Compound 8, a pterostilbene derivative, showed strong anti-inflammatory activity (IC50 = 0.6 μM against NO) by inhibiting the NF-κB/MAPK pathway and effectively alleviated DSS-induced acute colitis in mice with good safety in acute toxicity experiments.
population_specificity: LPS-treated RAW 264.7 cells and DSS-induced acute colitis in mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified for pterostilbene; compound 8 tested at IC50 = 0.6 μM in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether Ptd-1 (a derivative of Pterostilbene) could alleviate vascular calcification in mouse models and human aortic smooth muscle cells.
results_summary: Ptd-1 significantly reduced atherosclerosis progression, intimal and medial calcification, lipid deposition, and calcium salt deposition in mice. It also attenuated inflammatory factors (IL-1β, TNFα, IL-6) and disrupted ERK1/2 and β-catenin signaling pathways.
population_specificity: ApoE-deficient mice, wild-type mice, and human aortic smooth muscle cells (HASMCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the distribution of pterostilbene in ischemic rat brains and explore its potential mechanisms in treating cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury.
results_summary: Pterostilbene significantly restored cerebral microcirculation, reduced infarct volume, improved neurological function, and ameliorated neuronal damage in ischemic rats. It also restored energy supply, rebalanced neurotransmitters, and reduced abnormal polyamine accumulation and phospholipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Ischemic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene could reduce neuroinflammation and brain injury after intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) in mice and explore its underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: Pterostilbene improved neurological behavior, reduced lesion volume and neural apoptosis, alleviated blood-brain barrier damage and brain edema, and suppressed neuroinflammation and microglial proinflammatory activities by promoting mitochondrial fusion via OPA1 upregulation.
population_specificity: Mice with collagenase-induced intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH).
effective_dosage: 10 mg/kg, administered once daily via intraperitoneal injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the protective mechanisms, pharmacokinetics, and safety of pterostilbene in in vitro and in vivo models of CNS disorders to assess its potential therapeutic effects.
results_summary: Pterostilbene demonstrated protective effects in CNS disorders through mechanisms like antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activity, regulation of lipid metabolism, improvement of synaptic function, and inhibition of glioma cell migration. Possible molecular targets included AMPK/STAT3, Akt, NF-κB, MAPK, and ERK signaling pathways.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo models of CNS disorders (not specified for humans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms behind pterostilbene's neuroprotective effects against cerebral ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury.
results_summary: Pterostilbene reduced cerebral infarction volume, improved neurological deficits, enhanced cerebral microcirculation, and stabilized the blood-brain barrier (BBB) by targeting MMP-9 and modulating the Wnt pathway. It also maintained endothelial cytoskeleton integrity and extracellular matrix stability during early and late stages of I/R injury.
population_specificity: In vivo models (middle cerebral artery occlusion) and in vitro models (oxygen-glucose deprivation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiadipogenic and antiobesogenic efficacy of pterostilbene in 3T3-L1 adipocyte cells.
results_summary: Pterostilbene reduced lipid accumulation in adipocyte differentiation, improved spindle-like morphology, and increased Glut-4 and adiponectin levels without significant cytotoxicity at concentrations ≤7.5 µM.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 adipocyte cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the protective effect and potential mechanism of PS-GA-RGD nanomedicine on dry eye disease in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: PS-GA-RGD demonstrated significant anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects, reduced ROS and NLRP3 inflammasomes, and enhanced cellular uptake and corneal retention, showing superior efficacy compared to unmodified PS. It also prevented corneal epithelial cell defects and apoptosis while protecting conjunctival goblet cells.
population_specificity: Murine macrophages (RAW 264.7), human corneal epithelial cells, and experimental dry eye animal models (rabbits).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene (PTE) could mitigate diabetes-induced depression-like behavior in male Wistar rats with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: PTE significantly reduced depressive-like behavior, improved glucose tolerance, reduced insulin resistance, lowered cortisol and inflammatory markers, and enhanced SIRT1 gene expression. It also restored blood glucose, lipid profiles, and organ morphology.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with T2DM induced by nicotinamide and streptozotocin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the aqueous solubility of pterostilbene (PTB) using modified cyclodextrins (CDs) to enhance its potential for medicinal applications.
results_summary: The study successfully formed inclusion complexes of PTB with various CDs, significantly enhancing its solubility by 700-fold to 1250-fold. Complexation was confirmed in both solid-state and aqueous solutions, with association constants ranging from 15,000 to 55,000 M-1.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-obesity effects of pterostilbene and resveratrol, focusing on their mechanisms, including thermogenic activation and lipid metabolism alteration.
results_summary: The study suggests pterostilbene and resveratrol may aid weight loss by increasing metabolic rate, thermogenesis, and altering lipid metabolism, with potential in obesity prevention and treatment. However, optimal dosage, long-term safety, and mechanisms require further investigation.
population_specificity: Obese individuals (general, not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to design and evaluate novel pterostilbene derivatives for their antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects, particularly in treating heart failure.
results_summary: Compound E1, a pterostilbene dihydropyrazole derivative, showed potent anti-inflammatory and antioxidant activities by inhibiting NF-κB signaling and enhancing Nrf2-mediated antioxidant enzyme expression, improving doxorubicin-induced heart failure in mice.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 cells, H9C2 cells, and a mouse model of heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether pterostilbene (Pte) could mitigate oxidative stress and neurological dysfunction induced by chronic intermittent hypoxia (CIH) in mice.
results_summary: Pterostilbene improved neurological function, reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA), enhanced antioxidant enzymes (SOD, GSH-PX), modulated immune responses (Th2/Treg upregulation, Th1/Th17 downregulation), and inhibited gliocyte activation via p-ERK signaling to protect nerve cells.
population_specificity: CIH-induced mouse model (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of novel Pterostilbene-loaded solid lipid nanoparticles (CS/Lf/PTS-SLNs) as a targeted therapy for breast cancer, focusing on overcoming solubility, bioavailability, and stability limitations.
results_summary: CS/Lf/PTS-SLNs demonstrated superior cytotoxicity, anti-migratory effects, and cellular uptake compared to PTS-solution, achieving a 2.4-fold decrease in tumor growth in vivo and enhanced molecular suppression of VEGF, cyclin D1, and upregulation of caspase-3 and BAX.
population_specificity: Triple-negative MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells and an orthotopic cancer model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the miR-21-modulatory potential of PTER-ITC in drug-resistant breast cancer cell lines to assess its therapeutic potential.
results_summary: PTER-ITC effectively reduced survival of drug-resistant breast cancer cells by inducing apoptosis, inhibiting migration and invasiveness, and significantly downregulating miR-21 expression while upregulating tumor suppressor genes.
population_specificity: Tamoxifen-resistant MCF-7 and 5-fluorouracil-resistant MDA-MB 231 breast cancer cell lines.
effective_dosage: IC50 values: 37.21 µM for TR/MCF-7, 47.00 µM for 5-FUR/MDA-MB 231.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Pterostilbene's inhibitory effect on inflammation-associated tumor metastasis and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Pterostilbene reduced lung metastasis, decreased proinflammatory cytokines (TNF-α and IL-6), inhibited neutrophil elastase activity, and prevented TSP-1 degradation, thereby suppressing tumor cell migration and reversing EMT marker expression.
population_specificity: Mice with LPS-induced lung inflammation and melanoma metastasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic impact of pterostilbene supplementation on liver metabolism in Wistar rats with induced liver steatosis.
results_summary: Pterostilbene supplementation altered the metabolism of vitamins and derivatives, among other metabolites, in rats with liver steatosis, demonstrating distinct effects compared to resveratrol. The study highlighted 34 metabolites affected by the different diets, with ion mobility separation aiding in metabolite identification.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with induced liver steatosis fed a high-fat and high-fructose diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chemopreventive effects of pterostilbene (PS) and a probiotic (PRO) on colorectal cancer precursor lesions in a rat model of intestinal carcinogenesis induced by 1,2-DMH.
results_summary: PRO alone and PRO combined with PS were the most effective interventions in improving several parameters of 1,2-DMH-induced colorectal carcinogenesis, suggesting potential preventive benefits.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Pterostilbene (PTN) on atopic dermatitis (AD) in mice, focusing on inflammation, oxidative stress, and cytokine levels.
results_summary: PTN reduced ear weight, skin thickness, thymus and spleen size, IgE levels, and inflammatory cells in diseased mice. It also decreased oxidative stress markers and inflammatory cytokines (IL-4, IL-6, TNF-α, NF-κB) in the skin.
population_specificity: Mice with DNCB-induced atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect and underlying mechanism of pterostilbene on oxidative damage in ovarian granulosa cells.
results_summary: Pterostilbene improved cell viability, reduced oxidative stress, and inhibited ferroptosis in ovarian granulosa cells exposed to H2O2. It upregulated Nrf2 transcription via histone acetylation, and Nrf2 inhibition reversed its therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Ovarian granulosa cell lines COV434 and KGN.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to reduce the toxicity of a pterostilbene derivative (compound 32) while maintaining its biological activity, particularly its anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: Compound D22, a novel pterostilbene derivative, demonstrated low toxicity and potent inhibitory efficacy against IL-1β production (IC50 = 2.41 μM) and NLRP3 inflammasome activation, showing significant therapeutic effects in a mouse model of acute colitis.
population_specificity: DSS-induced acute colitis mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pterostilbene (PTS) could alleviate hemin-mediated suppression of Nrf2 activation and M2 macrophage polarization, potentially offering therapeutic benefits for diabetic foot ulcers (DFU).
results_summary: PTS reversed hemin-induced suppression of Nrf2 activation and its downstream targets, restored M2 macrophage polarization, reduced proinflammatory responses, and lowered MMP2 expression under hyperglycemic conditions. Proteomic analysis also showed PTS suppressed cellular stress and inflammation markers.
population_specificity: IC-21 macrophages studied under normoglycemic and hyperglycemic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of pterostilbene on the proliferation and apoptosis of human melanoma cells, specifically amelanotic (C32) and melanotic (A2058) cell lines.
results_summary: Pterostilbene reduced the proliferation of both amelanotic and melanotic melanoma cells and induced apoptosis in amelanotic C32 cells via increased expression of BAX, CASP9, and CASP3 genes, caspase 3 activity, and DNA degradation. However, it did not activate apoptosis in the A2058 cell line.
population_specificity: Human melanoma cells (C32 and A2058 cell lines)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of pterostilbene on experimental pulmonary fibrosis, diabetes, and myocardial infarction, focusing on oxidative damage pathways.
results_summary: Pterostilbene significantly upregulated SOD and GSH levels while downregulating MDA levels, demonstrating effectiveness in improving oxidative damage-related conditions compared to control groups.
population_specificity: Animal models with experimental pulmonary fibrosis, diabetes, and myocardial infarction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Pterostilbene (PTE) could alleviate Fumonisin B1 (FB1)-induced cytotoxicity in porcine alveolar macrophages.
results_summary: PTE largely recovered FB1-induced cytotoxicity, apoptosis, pro-inflammatory cytokine production, and mitochondrial damage by inhibiting the JAK/STAT signaling pathway, specifically targeting JAK2 and STAT3 genes.
population_specificity: Porcine alveolar macrophages (3D4/21 cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pterostilbene could inhibit HCMV replication and elucidate its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Pterostilbene inhibited HCMV replication, reduced viral protein expression and DNA replication, and suppressed cellular senescence biomarkers. It primarily acted post-viral entry, with an IC50 of 1.315 μM and a selectivity index of 26.73.
population_specificity: Human diploid fibroblast WI-38 cells infected with HCMV Towne strain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pterostilbene could alleviate oxaliplatin-induced peripheral neuropathy (OIPN) and explore its potential mechanisms, including its combination with celecoxib.
results_summary: Pterostilbene effectively reduced neuropathic pain and motor impairments, restored histopathological changes, and attenuated inflammation, oxidative stress, and apoptosis markers. The combination with celecoxib showed comparable or enhanced relief of neuropathic pain.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)
interactions: Celecoxib (30 mg/kg/day) was studied in combination, but no other interactions were mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects and safety of PEGylated pterostilbene micelles (PTENPs) in treating inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and explore its potential mechanisms.
results_summary: PTENPs demonstrated strong anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory effects in vitro and in vivo, effectively ameliorating acute IBD by inhibiting TLR4 activation and suppressing NF-κB and MAPK signaling pathways, with low toxicity.
population_specificity: Colitis mice model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pterostilbene (Pte) and its metabolite pinostilbene (Pin) could enhance immune responses and suppress EV-D68 replication in human respiratory cells.
results_summary: Pte and Pin alleviated EV-D68-induced cytopathic effects, disrupted viral RNA replication (EC50 1.336–4.997 µM), and reduced infectious virion production without cytotoxicity. They also broadly suppressed replication in circulating EV-D68 strains.
population_specificity: Human respiratory cells infected with EV-D68.
effective_dosage: EC50 values ranged from 1.336 to 4.997 µM (specific dosing frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the chemo-preventive effects of oral pterostilbene during different stages of skin squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) development in mouse models.
results_summary: Oral pterostilbene significantly reduced tumor number and volume, improved skin histology, and decreased cell proliferation markers compared to the cancer control group. It also showed fewer invasive tumors and less severe cellular changes.
population_specificity: Female Institute of Cancer Research (ICR) mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the potential of Pterostilbene in reducing arthritis and peripheral neuropathy in CFA-induced arthritic rats.
results_summary: Pterostilbene significantly reduced inflammation, oxidative stress, and pain while improving motor activity and neurotransmitter levels in arthritic rats. It also mitigated cartilage damage and synovial hyperplasia.
population_specificity: CFA-induced arthritic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pterostilbene could mitigate endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and restore autophagic flux to improve colon inflammation and barrier dysfunction in IUGR piglets and TNF-α-treated Caco-2 cells.
results_summary: Pterostilbene inhibited ER stress, restored autophagic flux, reduced inflammatory cytokines and apoptosis, improved intestinal barrier function, and its positive effects were blocked by ER stress and autophagy inhibitors.
population_specificity: IUGR piglets and TNF-α-treated human colonic epithelial cells (Caco-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the therapeutic potential of Pterostilbene (PTS) across various diseases, focusing on its mechanisms, pharmacokinetics, and strategies to enhance bioavailability.
results_summary: PTS exhibits robust pharmacodynamic features, including better absorption and hepatic stability than resveratrol, with potential benefits for diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular disease, neurodegenerative disorders, and aging. The review highlights Nrf2-mediated effects in diabetes and discusses formulations to improve bio-accessibility.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad review of experimental and clinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary pterostilbene supplementation on physicochemical changes and gel properties of myofibrillar protein in chicken during short-term frozen storage.
results_summary: Pterostilbene reduced protein oxidation, maintained structural stability, and improved gel quality (strength, whiteness, water-holding capacity) in chicken myofibrillar protein. It also promoted a dense, homogeneous gel network structure.
population_specificity: Postmortem chicken breast muscle (in vitro study).
study_duration: Short-term frozen storage (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-osteoporotic potential of PTER-ITC in a glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis (GIOP) rat model and its bone formation potential in vitro, including identifying its molecular target.
results_summary: PTER-ITC demonstrated osteogenic differentiation potential in pre-osteoblastic cells and inhibited osteoclastogenesis by targeting the RANK/TRAF6 interaction. It also improved bone architecture, physiology, and histology in GIOP rats, supported by serum biomarker analysis.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats (in vivo) and pre-osteoblastic mouse MC3T3-E1, human hFOB 1.19, mouse RAW 264.7, and human THP-1 macrophagic cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a folate-modified pterostilbene-loaded polymeric micellar delivery system (F-Pt/M) to enhance blood-brain barrier penetration and brain tissue targeting for treating brain diseases.
results_summary: The study found that F-Pt/M significantly improved drug solubility, cytotoxicity against FR-overexpressing cells, and BBB penetration compared to free Pt. The system demonstrated sustained release behavior and enhanced brain targeting with a drug targeting index of 4.89.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using FR-overexpressing A172 cells and BBB models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic effects of Pterostilbene (PTE) on articular chondrocyte senescence and osteoarthritis (OA) and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PTE significantly reduced OA-related damage and inflammation in rats, decreased markers of cellular senescence, and inhibited key signaling pathways (PI3K/AKT/NF-κB) associated with OA progression.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with induced OA.

study_goal: To formulate and evaluate the oral anti-obesity effects of polymeric-based pterostilbene-loaded nanoparticles.
results_summary: PS/HPβCD-NPs showed improved bioavailability and anti-obesity effects, supported by histological examination, lipid profile, and gene/protein expression of obesity biomarkers. The nanoparticles demonstrated sustainable weight loss with minimal side effects.
population_specificity: High-fat-diet-induced obesity rat model and Caco-2 cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant properties of pterostilbene (PS) combined with carboxyl-chitosan modified graphene (CG) for treating dry eye disease caused by oxidative stress.
results_summary: PS-CG demonstrated superior cellular permeability, sustained release, and antioxidant effects, reducing ROS levels, LDH content, and apoptosis in human corneal epithelial cells. In vivo tests showed increased tear production and healthier corneal and conjunctival epithelial cells in a dry eye mouse model.
population_specificity: Human corneal epithelial cells (HCEC) and a dry eye mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the oral bioavailability, organ/tissue distribution, and efficacy of a novel PTE pro-phytomicelle formulation against acetaminophen-induced liver damage in preclinical models.
results_summary: The PTE pro-phytomicelles significantly improved oral bioavailability and tissue distribution compared to bare PTE, and effectively reduced liver damage markers (ALT, AST), restored histopathology, and mitigated oxidative stress and inflammation via HMGB1 signaling regulation.
population_specificity: Rats and mice (preclinical animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pterostilbene-loaded PLGA nanoparticles could effectively inhibit Aspergillus brasiliensis biofilm formation and infection in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: PLGA-PTB-NPs reduced A. brasiliensis biofilm formation and mature biofilm, and in vivo experiments showed significantly lower mortality in infected larvae treated with PLGA-PTB-NPs compared to free PTB. The study demonstrated efficient nanoparticle uptake and enhanced PTB bioavailability in fungal biofilms.
population_specificity: Aspergillus brasiliensis (fungal biofilm model) and Galleria mellonella larvae (in vivo infection model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pterostilbene's ability to prevent intestinal epithelial barrier loss induced by high-intensity exercise in mice.
results_summary: Pterostilbene (100 mg/kg/d) significantly attenuated exercise-induced intestinal epithelial barrier loss, maintained high intestinal concentrations for 12 hours, and promoted tight junction molecule expression in vitro, though it did not reverse exercise-induced increases in Alistipes abundance.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to forced running as an exercise model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pterostilbene could reduce ectopic lipid deposition and renal fibrosis in high-fat diet-induced diabetic mice.
results_summary: Pterostilbene reduced ectopic lipid deposition, improved kidney function, and alleviated renal fibrosis by inhibiting the TGF-β1/smad3 signaling pathway. It also lowered protein levels of SREBP-1 and FAS, markers linked to lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced diabetic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the laxative effect of Pterostilbene (PTE) on loperamide-induced slow transit constipation (STC) in mice and its influence on intestinal microbes.
results_summary: PTE significantly improved intestinal motility, reduced apoptosis of Cajal interstitial cells, enhanced PI3K/AKT and Nrf2/HO-1 signaling pathways, lowered oxidative stress, and restored gut microbial diversity in STC mice.
population_specificity: Loperamide-induced slow transit constipation (STC) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of pterostilbene on vascular dementia (VaD) and explore its underlying mechanisms using in vivo and in vitro models.
results_summary: Pterostilbene attenuated cognitive impairment in mice with bilateral common carotid artery occlusion (BCCAO), reduced hippocampal neuronal death and microglial activation, and inhibited TLR4 and downstream inflammatory cytokines. The anti-inflammatory effect was linked to Triad3A-mediated TLR4 degradation.
population_specificity: Mice with BCCAO and oxygen-glucose deprivation and reperfusion (OGD/R)-stimulated BV-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of pterostilbene (Pt) and its derivative 3'-hydroxypterostilbene (OHPt) on lipid accumulation in HepG2 cells and NAFLD in C57BL/6J mice, focusing on SIRT1/AMPK and insulin signaling pathways.
results_summary: Pt and OHPt significantly reduced lipid accumulation in HepG2 cells and hepatic lipid droplets in mice, upregulated SIRT1/AMPK, and improved insulin resistance. OHPt was more effective than Pt, and both compounds positively altered gut microbiota.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells and C57BL/6J mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene (PTS) could protect myocardial function in septic mice by reducing inflammation and oxidative stress.
results_summary: PTS significantly improved cardiac function in septic mice, reduced inflammatory markers (IL-1α, IL-6, MCP-1, IL-1β, NLRP3), inhibited fibrosis (collagen I, collagen III, α-SMA), and decreased oxidative stress (NOX1, NOX2, NOX4, DHE levels).
population_specificity: Mice with sepsis induced by lipopolysaccharide (LPS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate pterostilbene's potential as a mitochondrial booster and its effects in combination with a mitochondrial cocktail (CoC3) on improving pathological alterations in mutant fibroblasts and induced neurons.
results_summary: Pterostilbene, particularly in combination with CoC3, enhanced sirtuins' activity and UPRmt activation, leading to improved pathological alterations in mutant fibroblasts and induced neurons. The positive effects were significantly increased when used in combination with CoC3.
population_specificity: Mutant fibroblasts and induced neurons (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene (PTS) could protect against doxorubicin (DOX)-induced hepatotoxicity in mice and HepG2 cells by examining its effects on oxidative stress, fibrosis, NLRP3 inflammasome stimulation, and apoptosis.
results_summary: PTS ameliorated DOX-induced liver damage by reducing oxidative stress, fibrosis, NLRP3 inflammasome activation, and apoptosis, while increasing antioxidant levels (SOD, GSH, Trx-1) and anti-apoptotic markers (BCL-2). In vitro, PTS reduced ROS and NLRP3 inflammasome levels and protected HepG2 cells from DOX-induced apoptosis.
population_specificity: C57/BL6J mice and HepG2 cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining pterostilbene (PTE) with sunitinib (SUN) enhances antitumor activity in gastric cancer cell lines and identifies potential mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that combining PTE with SUN significantly suppressed cell proliferation, increased oxidative stress, and retained mitochondrial Fe2+ in gastric cancer cells. In vivo, the combination showed pronounced antitumor effects compared to SUN alone, suggesting PDZD8 as a potential off-target for SUN.
population_specificity: Human gastric cancer cell lines (TMK1 and MKN74) and a nude mouse tumor model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of pterostilbene as an alternative medicine for cancer treatment, addressing drug resistance and metastatic recurrence.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding pterostilbene's effects, only mentioning cumulative evidence supporting its potential.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of pterostilbene (PTE) on the proliferation, differentiation, inflammation, and apoptosis of human periodontal ligament stem cells (hPDLSCs) and its potential role in periodontitis treatment.
results_summary: PTE promoted hPDLSC proliferation, reduced inflammatory factors, alleviated apoptosis, and enhanced mineralization. It also inhibited HDAC expression, suggesting a potential mechanism for its effects in periodontitis.
population_specificity: Human periodontal ligament stem cells (hPDLSCs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 6% Pueraria mirifica vaginal gel versus placebo on vaginal blood flow, tissue health, and genitourinary symptoms in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Pueraria mirifica gel significantly improved vaginal blood flow (reduced PI and RI), increased vaginal maturation index (VMI), and enhanced vaginal health index (VHI) compared to placebo after 12 weeks. All measured parameters showed statistically significant improvements in the treatment group.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM).
effective_dosage: 6% Pueraria mirifica vaginal gel (frequency not specified).

study_goal: To compare the effects of 5% Pueraria mirifica gel versus placebo on bacterial vaginosis, vaginal health, and genitourinary symptoms in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Pueraria mirifica gel significantly reduced abnormal Nugent scores and improved vaginal health index compared to placebo, but did not significantly alleviate genitourinary symptoms.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Pueraria mirifica gel and conjugated estrogen cream on vaginal health in postmenopausal women with vulvovaginal symptoms.
results_summary: Pueraria mirifica gel significantly improved vaginal maturation index and reduced vaginal symptoms, though conjugated estrogen cream showed greater efficacy in restoring vaginal epithelium. Both treatments were effective, with no significant difference in symptom relief between the two.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with at least one vulvovaginal symptom (dryness, soreness, irritation, dyspareunia, or discharge).
effective_dosage: 0.5 g intravaginally daily for 2 weeks, then three times per week for 10 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of Pueraria Mirifica extract, daidzein, and genistein on testosterone-induced prostatic hyperplasia in rats.
results_summary: The study found that Pueraria Mirifica extract, daidzein, and genistein reduced prostate/body weight ratio and improved prostatic cell histoarchitecture in testosterone-induced rats, indicating protective activity against benign prostatic hyperplasia.
population_specificity: Testosterone-induced prostatic hyperplasia in rats.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only testosterone dosage mentioned: 3 mg kg(-1)).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of miroestrol (MR) from Pueraria mirifica on antioxidant systems in the livers and uteri of normal and procarcinogen-exposed mice.
results_summary: MR improved antioxidant activities (SOD, CAT) in both normal and BNF-treated mice, increased glutathione levels in the liver, and reduced lipid peroxidation in the uterus. Estradiol (E2) showed similar but less consistent effects compared to MR.
population_specificity: β-naphthoflavone (BNF)-treated mice (a model of procarcinogen exposure) and normal mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-osteoporotic effects of Pueraria Mirifica in postmenopausal monkeys to assess its potential applicability for human use.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica treatment (1000 mg/kg BW) ameliorated cortical bone loss by reducing bone turnover, improving bone quantity (BMC and BMD) and quality (bone geometry), while untreated monkeys showed continuous cortical bone deterioration.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal osteoporotic monkeys (n=10, divided into two groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the neurotherapeutic effects of Pueraria mirifica extract (PME) and pure puerarin (PU) with 17β-estradiol (E2) in early- and late-stage cognitive impaired rats.
results_summary: PME and PU showed neurotherapeutic effects via different pathways, with PME improving estrogen deficiency symptoms and both reducing amyloid-related gene expression. Earlier treatment was more effective, with E2 showing the strongest cognitive improvement.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized (OVX) rats with early- and late-stage cognitive impairment.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg PME, 7 mg/kg PU, and 80 µg/kg E2 administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the estrogenic efficacy and systemic side effects of topical vaginal Pueraria mirifica extract in restoring vaginal atrophy in postmenopausal cynomolgus macaques.
results_summary: Pueraria mirifica significantly increased superficial vaginal cells and reduced vaginal pH, showing similar efficacy to conjugated equine estrogen (CEE) at 1% concentration, without causing systemic side effects observed with CEE.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal cynomolgus macaques with at least 5 years of complete cessation of menstruation.
effective_dosage: 0.1% or 1% (w/w) PM cream applied topically daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Pueraria Mirifica (PM) and its active phytoestrogen, miroestrol (MR), on oxidative status in ovariectomized (OVX) mice, comparing them to synthetic estradiol.
results_summary: PM and MR significantly increased glutathione (GSH) levels and the ratio of GSH to oxidized glutathione (GSSG) in the livers and uteri of OVX mice, while estradiol did not. They also restored the activities of antioxidative enzymes (GPx, SOD, CAT) to normal levels.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized (OVX) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Pueraria mirifica extract and its major isoflavone, puerarin, on osteoblast differentiation and proliferation in rat osteoblast-like cells to understand its potential role in preventing postmenopausal osteoporosis.
results_summary: Pueraria mirifica extract and puerarin significantly increased markers of osteoblast differentiation (ALP and osteoprotegerin) and decreased an osteoclastogenic factor, suggesting a dual mechanism for bone gain. These effects were ER-dependent, as they were abolished by an estrogen receptor antagonist.
population_specificity: Rat osteoblast-like UMR106 cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness and safety of Pueraria mirifica at 25 mg and 50 mg dosages in relieving menopausal symptoms in hysterectomized women.
results_summary: Both dosages of Pueraria mirifica significantly reduced menopausal symptoms over 6 months, with no significant difference between the two doses. No significant side effects were observed.
population_specificity: 52 hysterectomized women with menopausal symptoms requiring hormone therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the estrogen-like effects of Pueraria Mirifica on vaginal and urethral cytology, bladder function, and leak point pressure in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica (100 and 1,000 mg/kg/day) increased vaginal and urethral superficial cells and leak point pressure, similar to estradiol, but did not affect bladder capacity or residual urine volume.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized female Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Pueraria Mirifica on lipid metabolism in postmenopausal women and explore the underlying molecular mechanisms involving estrogen receptors.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica significantly increased HDL cholesterol and apo A-1 while decreasing LDL cholesterol, apo B, and their ratios, suggesting beneficial effects on lipid metabolism. Phytoestrogens in PM, particularly miroestrol and coumestrol, activated both ERalpha and ERbeta, while others like daidzein and genistein preferentially activated ERbeta.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pueraria Mirifica could prevent bone loss in ovariectomized rats, modeling postmenopausal osteoporosis.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica dose-dependently prevented bone loss in ovariectomized rats, with complete prevention at higher doses (100 and 1000 mg/kg), comparable to estrogen treatment. Effects varied by bone type, site, and compartment.
population_specificity: Fully mature ovariectomized rats (modeling postmenopausal women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pueraria Mirifica affects synaptic density by inducing synaptophysin expression via estrogen receptors.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica and 17beta-estradiol significantly increased synaptophysin immunoreactivity and levels after 4 days of treatment, with a dose-related effect up to 60 µg/ml. The effect was blocked by an estrogen receptor antagonist, indicating estrogen receptor involvement.
population_specificity: Hippocampal primary cell cultures at 6 days in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the mutagenic and antimutagenic activity of Pueraria Mirifica and Pueraria Lobata extracts using the Ames test and other assays.
results_summary: The study found that Pueraria Mirifica exhibited no mutagenic activity and demonstrated antimutagenic effects against specific mutagens. The extracts were non-toxic and safe at tested doses.
population_specificity: Salmonella typhimurium strains TA98 and TA100 (in vitro), rats (in vivo).
effective_dosage: 2.5, 5, 10, or 20 mg/plate (in vitro); up to 300 mg/kg body weight (in vivo).

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of Pueraria mirifica on lipid profiles, bone turnover rates, and safety in postmenopausal women, including its impact on endometrial, breast, hepatic, and renal systems.
results_summary: Pueraria mirifica showed an estrogen-like effect on bone turnover but not on endometrial thickness or histology. Both Pueraria mirifica and placebo increased triglyceride levels, with no significant adverse effects on breast tissue, blood counts, or liver and renal function.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women aged 45-60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Pueraria Mirifica (PM) against conjugated equine estrogen (CEE) with/without medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA) in alleviating climacteric symptoms in perimenopausal women.
results_summary: PM showed similar efficacy to CEE in reducing climacteric symptoms, with no statistically significant differences in symptom relief or serum hormone levels between the two groups. The study concluded that PM has estrogenic effects comparable to CEE and is effective for symptom alleviation.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal women with climacteric symptoms attending a menopausal clinic.
effective_dosage: 50 mg daily (PM group); 0.625 mg CEE with/without 2.5 mg MPA daily (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of long-term Pueraria Mirifica administration on ovarian function and fertility in adult female mice.
results_summary: PM at 10 mg/kg BW/day showed no adverse effects, while 100 mg/kg BW/day and synthetic estrogen (DES) disrupted estrous cycles, reduced mating efficiency, and altered ovarian histology, though pregnancy and offspring health were unaffected.
population_specificity: Adult female mice
effective_dosage: 0, 10, or 100 mg/kg BW/day (oral); 200 µg/kg BW/day DES (subcutaneous)

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of Pueraria mirifica on vaginal symptoms, vaginal health index, pH, and cytology in healthy postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Pueraria mirifica reduced vaginal dryness, improved vaginal maturation index, and restored atrophic vaginal epithelium without significant adverse effects compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women aged 45-60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Pueraria Mirifica on urinary hormone levels (FSH, LH, estradiol, progesterone) in female monkeys after single-dose and long-term treatments.
results_summary: Single-dose and daily 10 mg PM treatments showed no changes in hormone levels. Daily 100 mg and 1,000 mg PM treatments for 90 days reduced urinary FSH levels, suggesting FSH as an indicator of estrogenic effects.
population_specificity: Female monkeys (Macaca fascicularis)
effective_dosage: 10, 100, or 1,000 mg orally (single-dose and daily for 90 days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pueraria Mirifica could prevent bone loss in orchidectomized male rats without affecting reproductive organs.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica dose-dependently prevented bone loss in trabecular and cortical bones without altering the weights of accessory sex organs. The effects varied by bone type and site.
population_specificity: Orchidectomized male rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the estrogenic activity of Pueraria mirifica samples from different Thai provinces using a vaginal cornification assay in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: Pueraria mirifica showed dose-dependent estrogenic activity, with 100 mg/kg BW inducing vaginal cornification in 13 out of 25 samples and 1,000 mg/kg BW producing consistent effects. The onset of cornification was faster with 1,000 mg/kg BW (4.08 days) compared to 2 mg/kg BW estradiol (2 days), but the overall duration of cornification was shorter.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Pueraria Mirifica on reproductive organs and fertility in adult male mice, comparing it to synthetic estrogen.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica at 10 and 100 mg/kg BW/d showed no significant effects on testicular weight, sperm count, or hormone levels, though the higher dose reduced epididymal/seminal vesicle weight and sperm motility. No persistent effects or fertility impairments were observed, and mating efficiency improved post-treatment.
population_specificity: Adult male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pueraria Mirifica improves endothelial function and cardiovascular health in ovariectomized rabbits, focusing on nitric oxide-dependent pathways and vascular responses.
results_summary: PM improved endothelial function by enhancing nitric oxide production, increasing responsiveness to estrogen, and reducing sensitivity to norepinephrine, without affecting lipid profiles or liver enzymes.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized White New Zealand rabbits

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the estrogenic effect of Pueraria Mirifica by studying changes in sexual skin coloration in aged menopausal monkeys.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica induced reddish sexual skin coloration within 24 hours of treatment, which persisted for the first half of the feeding period. The effect was not dose-dependent, indicating estrogenic action.
population_specificity: Aged menopausal cynomolgus monkeys (n=9, divided into three groups).
study_duration: 90-day treatment period (preceded by 30-day pre-treatment and followed by 60-day post-treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the mutagenic effects of Pueraria Mirifica and the potential antimutagenic activity of Thunbergia laurifolia against these effects.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica at doses of 600 and 800 mg/kg induced higher frequencies of micronuclei, indicating mutagenic activity. Thunbergia laurifolia extracts significantly inhibited this mutagenic effect when combined with Pueraria Mirifica.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Pueraria Mirifica on gonadotrophin and estradiol levels in aged menopausal monkeys.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica suppressed gonadotrophin levels (FSH and LH) in a dose-dependent manner, with higher doses showing more prolonged effects post-treatment. Estradiol levels tended to decrease during treatment, and effects were reversible after discontinuation.
population_specificity: Aged menopausal cynomolgus monkeys (n = 9).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Pueraria Mirifica on menstrual cycle length and related reproductive hormones in adult female monkeys.
results_summary: Pueraria Mirifica significantly increased menstrual cycle length at lower doses (10 and 100 mg/d) and completely suppressed menstruation at the highest dose (1000 mg/d). Hormonal levels (FSH, LH, estradiol, progesterone, and inhibin) decreased dose-dependently during treatment, with recovery post-treatment only in the lower-dose groups.
population_specificity: Adult female monkeys (Macaca fascicularis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Pueraria Mirifica on serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) and calcium levels in aged menopausal monkeys.
results_summary: PM-1,000 mg/day significantly decreased PTH and calcium levels during treatment, with effects persisting for 15 days post-treatment. PM-10 mg/day also showed significant but less consistent effects, while PM-100 mg/day had no impact. Estradiol levels decreased in all treatment groups.
population_specificity: Aged menopausal monkeys (Macaca fascicularis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preliminary efficacy and safety of Pueraria mirifica in alleviating vasomotor symptoms (e.g., hot flushes, night sweats) in pre- and postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Pueraria mirifica reduced climacteric symptoms, as measured by the modified Greene climacteric scale, with both 50 mg and 100 mg doses showing improvement over six months. Some transient adverse effects (e.g., anemia, liver profile changes) were noted, but hormonal and lipoprotein changes were minor.
population_specificity: Pre- and postmenopausal women with vasomotor symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Pueraria mirifica, containing phytoestrogens, on the reproductive systems of gonadectomized male and female rats.
results_summary: Pueraria mirifica attenuated LH levels in both sexes and FSH levels in females at the highest dose (1,000 mg/kg), with effects recovering post-treatment. It increased uterine weight and vaginal cornification in females and epididymis weight in males, indicating greater reproductive system influence in females.
population_specificity: Gonadectomized male and female rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the estrogenic effect of Pueraria Mirifica (PM) using recombinant yeast, MCF-7 cell proliferation, and HepG2 cell transient transfection assays.
results_summary: PM showed no estrogenic activity in the yeast system but induced estrogenic effects in MCF-7 and HepG2 cells in a dose-dependent manner, which was blocked by tamoxifen. The results suggest PM may require metabolic activation for estrogenic activity.
population_specificity: In vitro cell lines (MCF-7 and HepG2 cells) and recombinant yeast.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of red pumpkin seed (RPS) extract on melanosome transfer to keratinocytes and its role in mitigating UVB-induced oxidative stress.
results_summary: The RPS extract suppressed melanosome transfer stimulated by UVB or H2O2 by activating the Nrf2 antioxidant pathway, reducing intracellular ROS levels, and downregulating POMC mRNA expression.
population_specificity: Keratinocytes in vitro (cell culture study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the bioactivity of pumpkin seed extract, particularly its effects on steroid-hormone receptors and its potential to inhibit the growth of cancer and hyperplastic cells.
results_summary: The study found no transactivational activity for androgen, estrogen, or progesterone receptors but observed significant cell growth inhibition (~40-50%) in prostate, breast, and colon cancer cells, as well as benign hyperplastic cells, with minimal effect on non-hyperplastic fibroblasts (~20%).
population_specificity: In vitro human cell lines (prostate cancer, breast cancer, colorectal adenocarcinoma, benign prostate hyperplasia, and dermal fibroblasts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pumpkin seed extract could protect against cyclophosphamide-induced reproductive toxicity in rats by examining sperm characteristics, biochemical parameters, and epididymal histology.
results_summary: Pumpkin seed extract significantly improved sperm characteristics, increased total antioxidant capacity, and reduced histopathological damage in CP-treated rats, suggesting protective effects against reproductive toxicity.
population_specificity: Male adult Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Punarnava Mandura and Dhatri Lauha in treating Garbhini Pandu (anemia during pregnancy).
results_summary: Punarnava Mandura showed better clinical improvement and a statistically significant increase in hemoglobin levels compared to Dhatri Lauha, with no adverse drug reactions reported.
population_specificity: 24 pregnant women with symptoms of Garbhini Pandu.
effective_dosage: Two 500 mg tablets of Punarnava Mandura thrice daily with 100 ml buttermilk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate pumpkin seed extract as a prophylactic and treatment for DMH-induced colon cancer in Wistar rats.
results_summary: Pumpkin seed extract significantly reduced aberrant crypt foci (ACF), improved antioxidant levels (GSH and SOD), decreased nitrite content, and reduced hyperplasia in treated groups compared to controls. Pretreatment at 200 mg/kg showed notable benefits in colon health metrics.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the Panduhara and Rasayana effects of Punarnava Mandura in managing geriatric anemia (Pandu Roga).
results_summary: Punarnava Mandura showed significant improvement in anemia symptoms, quality of life, and clinical features like Dehabala, Agni Bala, and Sattwa Bala, with moderate to mild improvement observed in 30% and 70% of patients, respectively.
population_specificity: 50 clinically diagnosed geriatric anemia patients (40 completed treatment).
effective_dosage: 2 tablets (250 mg each) twice daily after meals with buttermilk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiproliferative and immunomodulatory properties of Punarnava (Boerhaavia diffusa) root extract, specifically its effects on HeLa cell growth and cell cycle.
results_summary: The methanol:chloroform fraction (BDF 5) of Punarnava root extract significantly reduced HeLa cell proliferation after 48 hours at 200 μg/mL, inducing apoptosis via DNA fragmentation and caspase-9 activation. The antiproliferative effect was linked to inhibition of DNA synthesis in the S-phase of the cell cycle.
population_specificity: HeLa cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of repeated fumigation and a sorghum sudangrass cover crop on controlling purple nutsedge populations in tomato production.
results_summary: DMDS + metam potassium was the most effective fumigant for purple nutsedge control, while the sorghum cover crop unexpectedly increased purple nutsedge density compared to chemical fallow.
population_specificity: Tomato production fields in Florida infested with purple nutsedge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an oil-free hydroethanolic pumpkin seed extract on symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in men.
results_summary: The study found a significant 30.1% reduction in total IPSS, improved quality of life, decreased nocturia, and reduced postvoid residual urine volume after 12 weeks of supplementation. The extract was well-tolerated and effective in alleviating BPH-related symptoms.
population_specificity: 60 men (average age 62.3 years) with symptomatic BPH.
effective_dosage: Once daily before bedtime (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare cold tolerance among different nutsedge species, including Purple Nutsedge, by analyzing lipid composition and metabolic changes during cold exposure.
results_summary: Purple Nutsedge showed the lowest cold tolerance among the studied species, with minimal lipid content (<1% of dry weight) and no significant changes in starch, sugar, or protein content during cold exposure. Its lipid ratios and metabolic responses were less adaptive to cold compared to yellow nutsedge ecotypes.
population_specificity: Tubers of Purple Nutsedge (Cyperus rotundus L.) and yellow nutsedge ecotypes (Cyperus esculentus L.).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of elevated CO2 levels on the efficacy of glyphosate and halosulfuron for controlling purple and yellow nutsedge.
results_summary: Elevated CO2 increased the growth of purple nutsedge (shoot and root dry weights) and yellow nutsedge (shoot, root, and tuber dry weights and counts). Both herbicides effectively controlled both species at all tested rates, regardless of CO2 concentration.
population_specificity: Purple and yellow nutsedge grown in 3.0-L containers under ambient or elevated CO2 conditions.
effective_dosage: 0.5×, 1.0×, or 1.5× of the manufacturer's labeled rate of halosulfuron, glyphosate, or a tank mix of both.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the estrogenic effect of Pueraria mirifica on menstrual cycle length and ovarian hormone-related function in monkeys.
results_summary: A single dose of 1,000 mg of P. mirifica significantly increased follicular phase and total menstrual cycle length in monkeys, but no hormonal changes were observed. Lower doses (10 and 100 mg) showed no effect on cycle length or hormone levels.
population_specificity: Nine normal cyclic monkeys (Macaca fascicularis).
study_duration: One and two menstrual cycles post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether purslane extract could reduce intestinal inflammation associated with obesity by modulating the TLR4/NF-κB signaling pathway.
results_summary: Purslane extract reduced bowel inflammation and colon shortening in obese mice by suppressing the TLR4/NF-κB pathway, leading to decreased levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines TNF-α and IL-6.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice fed a high-fat diet to induce obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of purslane extract on endothelial function and the underlying mechanisms in diabetic-associated endothelial dysfunction.
results_summary: Purslane extract ameliorated impairments in endothelial function, reduced ER stress and oxidative stress, and activated AMPK/eNOS signaling in both cell cultures and diabetic obese mice. The effects were abolished by an AMPK inhibitor, indicating the mechanism of action.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice and primary rat aortic endothelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Purslane Extract (PE) in improving glucose control, blood pressure, and lipid profile in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) already on a single oral hypoglycemic agent.
results_summary: PE significantly reduced systolic blood pressure in the total cohort and HbA1c in the subgroup of responders, with few mild adverse events reported. The effects were statistically significant but modest in clinical magnitude.
population_specificity: Adults with T2DM (mean age 52.4–58.3 years) treated with a single oral hypoglycemic agent at baseline.
effective_dosage: Three capsules of PE per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and preventive effects of Pycnogenol® on residual symptoms and recurrence in patients with vasculitis-related conditions during remission.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® significantly reduced symptom scores, ESR values, IL-6 levels, and oxidative stress while decreasing the need for NSAIDs or corticosteroids compared to controls. No side effects were reported.
population_specificity: 124 otherwise healthy subjects with systemic lupus erythematosus, Behçet's disease, Sjögren Syndrome, or polyarteritis nodosa in remission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of ultrasonic coupling with purslane extract in inhibiting enzymatic browning in fresh-cut potatoes during storage.
results_summary: The study found that combining ultrasonic treatment with a low concentration of purslane extract (0.02%) was more effective at preventing browning than using purslane extract alone (0.05%). The combination significantly reduced enzyme activity (PPO and POD), preserved cell membrane integrity, and enhanced antioxidant capacity during storage.
population_specificity: Fresh-cut potato samples stored at 4°C.
effective_dosage: 0.02% (w/w) purslane extract combined with 10-minute ultrasonic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol® could protect against noise-induced hearing loss in a rat model.
results_summary: The study found that Pycnogenol® significantly improved auditory brainstem response thresholds and preserved cochlear morphology in rats exposed to noise, suggesting potential protective effects against noise-induced hearing loss.
population_specificity: Male Wistar albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol (PYC) could alleviate pulmonary toxicity induced by titanium dioxide nanoparticles (TiO2NPs) and explore its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant mechanisms.
results_summary: PYC reduced TiO2NP-induced pulmonary inflammation, mucus production, oxidative stress markers, and restored glutathione levels in mice. It also demonstrated antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects in human airway epithelial cells by modulating TXNIP, cleaved-Cas3, and inflammatory mediators.
population_specificity: Mice and human airway epithelial cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol® improves patient-reported health status and mitigates symptoms in individuals with post-COVID-19 condition (PCC).
results_summary: The abstract does not report results, as the study appears to be ongoing or recently completed without published outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with post-COVID-19 condition (PCC), stratified by symptom duration (≤6 months vs. >6 months) and presence of chronic diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active components of Pycnogenol and elucidate their anti-inflammatory mechanisms using UPLC-MS/MS, network pharmacology, and cell experiments.
results_summary: The study identified 768 compounds in Pycnogenol, with 19 showing anti-inflammatory effects targeting 85 proteins, particularly IL6, TNF, and IL1B. Cell experiments confirmed Pycnogenol reduced IL6 and IL1β expression in LPS-induced BV2 cells, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects via IL17 and TNF pathways.
population_specificity: LPS-induced BV2 cells (microglial cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pro-apoptotic and anti-migrative effects of pycnogenol in a breast cancer cell line (MCF-7).
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced cell viability, induced apoptosis (evidenced by chromatin condensation and nuclear fragmentation), and inhibited migration in MCF-7 cells by downregulating Bcl-2, VEGF/FGF, and p53 mRNA expression. The inhibitory concentration (IC-50) was observed at 80 μg/mL.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cell line (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the efficiency of Molnupiravir for COVID-19 therapy by modifying it with Pycnogenol and cellulose nanoparticles decorated with zinc oxide.
results_summary: The modified drug showed improved release efficiency (65-78%) and higher biological activity, including antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects, with the ZnO nanocomposite performing best. Viral inhibition was modest (18.02-37.6%).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or cell line study).
effective_dosage: 400-800 µg/ml (concentration used in viral inhibition assay).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the wound healing efficacy of Pycnogenol™, both alone and in combination with C. oestroides extract, using composite dressings in a mouse model.
results_summary: Pycnogenol™, either alone or combined with C. oestroides, failed to close wounds by the 16th day, with poor histological scores (15). It also appeared to induce skin thickening and increased body temperature.
population_specificity: SKH-hr2 hairless mice with surgical wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Pycnogenol combined with L-arginine (PAL) in improving sexual function in men with mild to moderate erectile dysfunction (ED).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant improvements in erectile function, intercourse satisfaction, orgasmic function, overall satisfaction, and sexual desire scores with PAL therapy compared to the control group, though no significant difference in testosterone levels was observed.
population_specificity: Men with mild to moderate erectile dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel hybrid nanocomposite (Cs@Pyc.SOF) combining Pycnogenol with sofosbuvir and chitosan nanoparticles to evaluate its potential as an anti-HCV therapy.
results_summary: The nanocomposite showed high drug loading efficiency (83%) and controlled release rates (up to 94% at 48 hours). Cytotoxicity tests indicated safety and high viability in mouse normal liver cells (BNL), suggesting potential as an HCV treatment, though clinical validation is needed.
population_specificity: Mouse normal liver cells (BNL) in vitro.
study_duration: Release rates measured up to 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects and therapeutic mechanisms of Pycnogenol post-treatment in a gerbil model of ischemia and reperfusion (IR) injury.
results_summary: Pycnogenol (100 mg/kg) significantly improved memory deficits, reduced blood-brain barrier leakage, and inhibited pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-1β expression, demonstrating neuroprotective effects against IR injury. Lower doses (25 and 50 mg/kg) did not show significant effects.
population_specificity: Gerbils subjected to ischemia and reperfusion injury in the forebrain.
effective_dosage: 25, 50, and 100 mg/kg, administered intraperitoneally immediately, at 24 hours, and 48 hours post-IR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of pycnogenol, indomethacin, and their combination (PI) in rats, as well as their impact on stomach tissue.
results_summary: Pycnogenol suppressed COX-2 expression and oxidative stress, reduced indomethacin-induced stomach ulcers, and enhanced anti-inflammatory activity when combined with indomethacin. It also inhibited malondialdehyde increase and preserved glutathione levels in stomach tissue.
population_specificity: Albino Wistar male rats
interactions: Positive interaction with indomethacin (PI combination showed superior anti-inflammatory effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the preventive effect of Pycnogenol supplementation on cognitive and motor symptoms in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly improved Karnofsky performance index, reduced oxidative stress, decreased peripheral edema, and alleviated key Parkinson's symptoms (tremor, bradykinesia, cognitive alterations, rigidity, speech impairment) and facial expression asymmetry compared to controls.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate, well-controlled Parkinson's disease under stable treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol could protect against organ damage caused by methotrexate (MTX) treatment.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced MTX-induced oxidative damage, toxicity, inflammatory response, and histological damage in the liver, kidney, and heart in a dose-dependent manner. Biochemical and histological analyses confirmed its protective effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal model implied by dosage units mg/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's protective effects against gamma radiation-induced lung damage in rats, focusing on histopathological changes, enzymatic alterations, and DNA damage.
results_summary: Pycnogenol (especially at 300 mg/kg) significantly increased CAT and SOD activities, reduced MDA levels, and decreased DNA damage and radiation-induced lung injury compared to the irradiated group without treatment.
population_specificity: Adult male rats exposed to whole-body gamma irradiation.
effective_dosage: 37.5 mg/kg, 75 mg/kg, 150 mg/kg, and 300 mg/kg administered orally 24, 48, and 72 hours before irradiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of topically applied Pycnogenol in healing alkaline corneal ulcers in diabetic and normal rats.
results_summary: Pycnogenol improved corneal epithelial wound healing in normal rats and significantly enhanced healing in diabetic rats compared to controls. It also reduced inflammatory cell infiltration in diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (normal and diabetic) with induced corneal alkali-burn injuries.
effective_dosage: PY eye drops applied three times daily (specific concentration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively review the evidence on Pycnogenol's physiological and pharmacological properties, focusing on its therapeutic potential for reducing inflammation and oxidative stress in chronic diseases.
results_summary: The study suggests Pycnogenol may reduce inflammation and oxidative stress by modulating insulin receptor signaling, inhibiting pro-inflammatory cytokines, and enhancing antioxidant pathways, though these effects are not yet fully proven.
population_specificity: Not specified (general chronic disease context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol could mitigate lung fibrosis and inflammation in mice exposed to PHMG.
results_summary: Pycnogenol improved body and lung weight, reduced inflammatory cytokines and fibrosis-related factors, and decreased histopathological signs of inflammation/fibrosis in a dose-dependent manner. The higher dose (1 mg/kg/day) showed more pronounced effects.
population_specificity: PHMG-treated mice (n = 6 per group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine Pycnogenol's effects on motor function, depression, and the expression of NF-ƙB and Nrf2 genes in a Parkinson's disease mouse model.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly improved motor function, reduced catalepsy and depression, and increased Nrf2 gene expression, but did not significantly affect NF-ƙB gene expression. It demonstrated neuroprotective effects through antioxidative and genomic mechanisms.
population_specificity: Adult male NMRI mice (Parkinson's disease model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if oral Pycnogenol® supplementation could improve skin health in Han Chinese individuals working outdoors in Beijing under high environmental stress.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® prevented declines in skin hydration, transepidermal water loss, and skin darkening during dry seasons, while also improving viscoelastic skin properties like elasticity and recovery. No such benefits were observed with placebo.
population_specificity: Han Chinese adults working outdoors in Beijing, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Pycnogenol could protect against oxidative alterations in testicular and brain tissues caused by heat stress in rats.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reversed heat-induced oxidative damage by upregulating antioxidant genes and reducing pro-apoptotic markers, while restoring reproductive hormone levels and spermatogenesis to normal.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (6 weeks old)
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg body weight/day, orally dissolved in saline

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of oral Pycnogenol (75 mg twice daily) versus placebo, combined with sunscreen and a topical triple combination, for treating facial melasma.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly improved melasma severity (mMASI scores), quality of life (MELASQoL), and colorimetric contrast compared to placebo, with no reported adverse effects. The treatment group showed a 49% reduction in mMASI scores versus 34% for placebo.
population_specificity: 44 women with facial melasma, predominantly phototypes III-IV, mean age 39 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the suitability of a Pycnogenol-loaded bioadhesive film for treating open wounds, focusing on its mechanical properties, release kinetics, and effects on keratinocytes.
results_summary: The film demonstrated good absorbency (~65% wt/wt within 1 h), mechanical adaptability (elastic modulus E = 3.070 ± 0.044 MPa), and sustained PYC release (~0.2 mg/mL over 24 h). PYC at 0.015 mg/mL stimulated keratinocyte growth without cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or ex vivo focus).
effective_dosage: Film released ~0.2 mg/mL PYC over 24 h, with 0.015 mg/mL achieved in the first 5 min.
study_duration: Not specified (release kinetics measured over 24 h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the neuroprotective effects and mechanisms of Pycnogenol® against ischemic injury following transient forebrain ischemia in gerbils.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® at 50 mg/kg protected learning, memory, and hippocampal pyramidal cells from ischemic injury, enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity, and reduced oxidative damage. Its neuroprotective effect was abolished by sodium azide, indicating an antioxidative mechanism.
population_specificity: Gerbils with induced transient forebrain ischemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the neuroprotective effects of Pycnogenol (PYC) on spinal cord injury (SCI) and determine its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PYC improved motor function, reduced neuronal apoptosis, stabilized mitochondrial membrane potential, decreased oxidative stress markers (MDA), and increased antioxidant activity (SOD) in SCI rats. It also modulated apoptosis-related proteins (Cleaved-caspase 3, Bax, Bcl-2) and reduced Cyt-c release.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced spinal cord injury.
study_duration: Single dose administered 15 minutes post-SCI (duration of follow-up not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Pycnogenol (PYC) on cisplatin cytotoxicity in human cervix cancer cells (HeLa) and evaluate its genotoxicity.
results_summary: PYC increased cisplatin cytotoxicity at certain concentrations and reduced oxidative DNA damage at lower doses but induced DNA damage at higher doses. The results suggest PYC may enhance cisplatin's anticancer effect at non-genotoxic doses.
population_specificity: Human cervix cancer cells (HeLa) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of a polyherbal medicine (including Pycnogenol) for reducing metabolic markers associated with pre-type 2 diabetes (pre-T2D).
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in impaired fasting glucose (IFG) or impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) in the intervention group compared to the control group. Blood cholesterol and triglyceride levels also remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Patients with pre-type 2 diabetes (pre-T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol supplementation improves clinical, nutritional, and inflammatory status in traumatic brain injury (TBI) patients.
results_summary: The study expects Pycnogenol to improve clinical and nutritional status while reducing inflammation and oxidative stress in TBI patients, though specific results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Pycnogenol® in treating primary, idiopathic mucosal dryness (xerostomia) in non-cancer subjects, comparing diabetics and non-diabetics.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® significantly improved salivary flow, reduced oxidative stress, decreased mucosal breaks and ulcerations, and increased lysozyme levels in both diabetic and non-diabetic subjects, with minimal improvements seen in the standard management group.
population_specificity: 48 subjects (24 diabetics and 24 non-diabetics) with a BMI <26 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pycnogenol supplementation on accessory symptoms and cognitive functions in Parkinson's Disease patients under stable neurological treatment.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation significantly attenuated target symptoms (tremor, bradykinesia, cognitive dysfunction, rigidity, speech changes) and reduced oxidative stress compared to standard management alone. Peripheral edema improved more in the supplemented group.
population_specificity: 43 Parkinson's Disease patients with mild, minimally progressive symptoms on carbidopa/levodopa monotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of pycnogenol on blood pressure through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical studies.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 7 trials involving 626 participants found no significant effect of pycnogenol on systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, mean arterial pressure, or pulse pressure. Results remained consistent in sensitivity analysis.
population_specificity: 626 participants across 7 randomized clinical trials (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol® could reduce migraine headache attacks and oxidative stress in otherwise healthy subjects with moderate migraine headaches.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® significantly reduced the number of migraine attacks, pain scores, working incapacity, and use of rescue medications compared to standard management. It also lowered oxidative stress levels, unlike standard management or topiramate.
population_specificity: Otherwise healthy subjects with moderate migraine headaches.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Pycnogenol® supplementation alongside standard management in reducing symptoms of mild, primary Raynaud syndrome compared to standard management alone.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® significantly reduced coldness, burning pain, paresthesias, and irregular color changes, improved finger temperature and skin flux, and decreased oxidative stress more than standard management alone. Fewer subjects in the Pycnogenol® group required additional drug treatment.
population_specificity: 67 females aged 30-40 with mild, primary Raynaud syndrome, working in shops with refrigerators.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's efficacy in controlling symptoms of chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) and improving microcirculatory parameters like venous hypertension and microangiopathy.
