results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly improved microcirculation, reduced oxidative stress, and alleviated CVI symptoms, outperforming compression stockings alone. The combination of Pycnogenol and compression yielded the best results.
population_specificity: 142 patients with chronic venous insufficiency during a summer period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's efficacy in reducing oxidative stress and side effects of levothyroxine (LT4) treatment in patients with primary hypothyroidism.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation significantly reduced the global occurrence of symptoms compared to the control group (P<0.05), suggesting it may help mitigate LT4-related side effects.
population_specificity: 60 females with primary hypothyroidism and multi-nodular goiter under initial LT4 treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Pycnogenol on ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury in rat brain tissues, focusing on oxidative and inflammatory damage.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reduced cortex damage, edema, and vasopathology in rats with I/R injury, lowered oxidative stress markers (MDA) and inflammatory markers (IL-1β, TNF-α), and improved antioxidant levels (GSH, GPO).
population_specificity: Albino Wistar rats
study_duration: 24 hours of reperfusion following 30 minutes of transient ischemia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's effectiveness in reducing recurrent retinal vein thrombosis (RVT) and its ability to control edema compared to other treatments.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced recurrent RVT incidence (3.3% vs. 22.7% in controls) and better controlled edema (present in only 5.5% of subjects). It also demonstrated excellent tolerability and safety with no treatment discontinuations.
population_specificity: Subjects with a first episode of retinal vein thrombosis (RVT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol (PYC) could attenuate escitalopram-induced sexual dysfunction (SDys) in patients with depression.
results_summary: PYC co-treatment reduced SDys starting at 1 month and sustained the effect for two consecutive months, while also increasing heart rate. The study suggests PYC's benefits may stem from its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and vasodilatory properties.
population_specificity: 72 outpatients (67 analyzed) of both genders with depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Pycnogenol on DNA damage and biochemical changes in diabetic rats, focusing on oxidative stress, lipid profile, liver function, and DNA integrity.
results_summary: Pycnogenol treatment significantly improved oxidative stress markers, lipid profiles, liver function parameters, and reduced DNA damage in hyperglycemic rats, suggesting potential benefits for diabetes-related complications.
population_specificity: Experimental diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Pycnogenol on PTZ-induced seizures in mice and assess its potential as an adjuvant therapy for epilepsy.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly increased seizure latency, reduced duration and frequency of convulsions, and improved biochemical markers (reduced TBARS, increased SOD, catalase, and GSH) without impairing cognitive functions or causing muscle relaxant effects. Histopathological findings showed less neuronal degeneration compared to controls.
population_specificity: Swiss strain mice weighing 18-30g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pycnogenol® supplementation on symptoms and inflammation in Sjögren syndrome patients in remission.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® significantly reduced ESR and oxidative stress levels, improved symptoms like dry eyes and mouth dryness, and decreased the need for corticosteroids and other treatments.
population_specificity: Otherwise healthy subjects with Sjögren syndrome in remission experiencing persistent symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol could prevent testosterone propionate-induced benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) in rats.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced prostate weight, dihydrotestosterone (DHT) levels in serum and prostate, and expression of PCNA and Ki-67 proteins compared to BPH-induced rats, indicating inhibition of BPH development.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Pycnogenol supplementation on blood pressure through a meta-analysis of existing studies.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation (150-200 mg/d) significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, particularly in hypertensive participants or those treated for over 12 weeks, though this effect was not observed in well-designed trials.
population_specificity: 549 participants across nine trials, including hypertensive individuals.
study_duration: Varied, with subgroup analysis for interventions longer than 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Pycnogenol on an experimental allergic conjunctivitis model in rats, comparing its efficacy and safety to dexamethasone.
results_summary: Pycnogenol (10 mg/kg) significantly reduced mast cell count and showed similar histological improvements to dexamethasone in alleviating allergic conjunctivitis symptoms, with no detrimental effects observed. Negative staining for TGF-β and weak focal staining for TNF-α were common in both treatment groups.
population_specificity: Rats with experimentally induced allergic conjunctivitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Pycnogenol on obesity and white adipose tissue browning in apolipoprotein E-deficient mice.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reversed body weight and fat mass gain induced by a high-cholesterol, high-fat diet, reduced adipocyte size, promoted lipolysis, and increased beige adipogenesis-related gene expression. It also activated the PKA signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Apolipoprotein E-deficient mice fed a high-cholesterol, high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pycnogenol® supplementation over two months in healthy individuals with mild cognitive impairment, as measured by MMSE scores.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® supplementation significantly improved MMSE scores (18% median increase) compared to standard management (2.48% increase), with no significant adverse effects reported. The results suggest Pycnogenol® may benefit cognitive function in individuals with mild impairment.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects with mild cognitive impairment (MMSE score 18-23) and BMI <26 kg/m², no metabolic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cellular mechanisms behind Pycnogenol's symptom-alleviating effects in patients with severe knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly downregulated cartilage degradation markers (MMP3, MMP13, IL1B) in chondrocytes and reduced ADAMTS-5 protein levels in serum, suggesting anti-inflammatory and cartilage-protective effects.
population_specificity: Patients with severe knee osteoarthritis scheduled for knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the beneficial effects of Pycnogenol on diet-induced hepatic steatosis in ApoE-deficient mice.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reduced body weight, serum lipids, and hepatic lipid deposition while suppressing genes related to lipogenesis and inflammation, thereby protecting against hepatic steatosis.
population_specificity: Apolipoprotein E (ApoE)-deficient male mice fed a high-cholesterol and high-fat diet.
study_duration: 2 weeks pre-treatment followed by 8 weeks of high-cholesterol and high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Pycnogenol on DNA damage and biochemical changes in blood, liver, and lung tissues of ischemia-reperfusion-induced rats.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (TOS, TTL, MPO, AOPP, ALT, AST, LDH) and DNA damage while increasing antioxidant status (TAS) compared to the IR group.
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats with induced ischemia-reperfusion injury.
study_duration: Single dose administered before IR inducement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol could mitigate pulmonary fibrosis and inflammation caused by cigarette smoke and LPS exposure in a mouse model of COPD.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reduced inflammatory cells and proinflammatory mediators, inhibited collagen deposition in lung tissue, and suppressed TGF-β1/Smad 2/3 signaling, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for COPD progression.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to cigarette smoke and LPS to model COPD.
effective_dosage: 10 and 20 mg/kg administered orally once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the in vivo distribution of constituents or metabolites of Pycnogenol in patients with severe osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found significant interindividual variability in polyphenol pharmacokinetics, with the highest concentrations detected in blood cells and synovial fluid rather than serum. Taxifolin and ferulic acid were exclusively or predominantly present in the Pycnogenol-treated group, suggesting targeted distribution.
population_specificity: 33 patients with severe osteoarthritis scheduled for knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Pycnogenol® to methylphenidate and placebo on behavior, immunity, oxidative stress, and physical symptoms in pediatric ADHD and ADD patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for Pycnogenol® but indicates the study evaluated behavior, immune markers, oxidative stress, and physical complaints, with an active control arm for comparison.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with ADHD and ADD (144 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pycnogenol (PYC) on wound healing in healthy and diabetic rats compared to untreated and cleanser/silver sulfadiazine-treated wounds.
results_summary: PYC-treated wounds showed significantly greater wound size reduction (58.03%) compared to untreated (45.73%) and cleanser/SSD-treated (48.73%) wounds. PYC also improved collagen deposition and neovascularization in diabetic rats compared to cleanser/SSD treatment.
population_specificity: 48 adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (24 healthy, 24 diabetic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Pycnogenol on allergic inflammation in a rat model of allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced levels of inflammatory markers (IL-4, IFN-γ, IL-10, TNF-α, IL-1β) and improved histopathological changes in nasal mucosa, demonstrating multiple suppressive effects on allergic response.
population_specificity: Rats with induced allergic rhinitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Pycnogenol in improving postpartum varicose veins (VVs) and venous function compared to elastic compression stockings.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced the number of veins, incompetent sites, edema, spider veins, and minor symptoms compared to controls, with higher patient satisfaction and compliance. Most improvements occurred within 6 months, and results remained stable at 12 months.
population_specificity: Healthy women after their second pregnancy with postpartum varicose veins.
study_duration: At least 3 months of follow-up, with re-evaluation at 6 and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's potential to improve HCV-associated type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and its antiviral effects against HCV replication.
results_summary: The study suggests Pycnogenol may enhance conventional HCV therapy, mitigate HCV-associated T2DM, and reduce complications like cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and cardiovascular disease. The review cites previously published data supporting its antidiabetic and antiviral properties.
population_specificity: Individuals with Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness and molecular mechanism of Pycnogenol (PYC) in regulating asthmatic airway inflammation, particularly its impact on the IL-13/JAK/STAT6 pathway and goblet cell metaplasia.
results_summary: PYC reduced ovalbumin-induced airway injury, inhibited inflammatory cells and cytokines (IL-4, IL-5, IL-9, IL-13), and suppressed the IL-13/JAK/STAT6 pathway, leading to decreased goblet cell metaplasia. PYC also showed high bioavailability (71.96%) and rapid absorption.
population_specificity: OVA-induced asthmatic mice
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg (tail intravenous injection) or 100 mg/kg (intragastric administration)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol (PYC) improves cognitive function and reduces brain damage following traumatic brain injury (TBI) in rats.
results_summary: PYC at the highest dose (100mg/kg) significantly reduced lesion volume but did not improve cognitive function in the Morris water maze or reduce hippocampal neuron degeneration (FJB staining). The study suggests oxidative stress and neuroinflammation reduction may not be key to cognitive recovery post-TBI.
population_specificity: Adult Sprague-Dawley rats with controlled cortical impact (CCI) injury.
study_duration: Evaluated at 48h (FJB staining) and 7 days post-trauma (MWM and lesion volume).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's efficacy, antioxidant, and antiapoptotic effects in a hypoxic-ischemic rat model.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reduced neuronal cell injury and apoptosis in the cerebral tissue of rats with hypoxic-ischemic brain injury. The study suggests Pycnogenol may protect against hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats on the seventh postnatal day with induced hypoxic-ischemic brain injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol could suppress atherosclerosis formation induced by a high cholesterol and fat diet in apolipoprotein E-deficient mice.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced atherosclerotic lesion size, suppressed oxidized LDL-induced lipid accumulation in macrophages, and inhibited TLR4 expression and related inflammatory pathways (aP2 and SR-A) via the JNK pathway.
population_specificity: Apolipoprotein E-deficient mice fed a high cholesterol and fat diet.
study_duration: 10 weeks (PYC administered for 10 weeks, with high cholesterol and fat diet during the latter 8 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's ability to inhibit chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in both human airway epithelial cells and a mouse model.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced inflammatory markers and mucus production in human cells and decreased inflammatory cell counts and cytokine levels in the COPD mouse model, primarily via the Erk-sp1 pathway.
population_specificity: Human airway epithelial cell line NCI-H292 and a cigarette smoke/lipopolysaccharide-induced mouse model.
effective_dosage: 15mg/kg and 30mg/kg administered 1h before cigarette smoke exposure in mice.
study_duration: 7 days (mice exposed to cigarette smoke for 1h/day from days 1-7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Pycnogenol and diosmin/hesperidin on venous ulcer healing in patients with chronic venous insufficiency.
results_summary: Pycnogenol showed a similar effect to diosmin/hesperidin in promoting venous ulcer healing and significantly reduced the circumference of affected limbs. Both treatments were effective, with statistically significant results (P < 0.0001).
population_specificity: 30 adult patients with venous ulcers from a vascular surgery outpatient clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Pycnogenol, alone or in combination with spirulina, against vancomycin-induced renal oxidative stress in rats.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reduced oxidative stress markers (e.g., malondialdehyde, Bax, LC3/B, inducible nitric oxide synthase) and improved antioxidant levels (e.g., glutathione, glutathione peroxidase, superoxide dismutase) and kidney function in vancomycin-treated rats. The combination of Pycnogenol and spirulina showed superior protective effects compared to monotherapy.
population_specificity: Rats (49 animals divided into 7 groups)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Pycnogenol as an add-on therapy to metformin in diabetic rats, focusing on cardiovascular and metabolic outcomes.
results_summary: Pycnogenol improved blood glucose levels, vascular reactivity, left ventricular hypertrophy, and expression of key proteins (AMPK, GLUT4, CaMKII) in the heart, but combining it with metformin did not enhance efficacy further.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol could protect against cisplatin-induced ototoxicity in rats.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced cisplatin-induced apoptosis in the organ of Corti and spiral ganglion neurons and improved auditory function, as measured by DPOAE, compared to cisplatin alone. The study concluded that Pycnogenol is protective against ototoxicity and is not ototoxic itself.
population_specificity: Rats (specifically, their auditory systems)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Pycnogenol's apoptotic effects and molecular mechanisms in human oral squamous cell carcinoma HSC-3 cells.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly inhibited HSC-3 cell viability, induced caspase-dependent apoptosis, increased Bak protein stability, and generated reactive oxygen species, suggesting potential for oral cancer chemoprevention or chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Human oral squamous cell carcinoma HSC-3 cells and TPA-treated JB6 cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine Pycnogenol's protective effects against atherosclerosis and its underlying mechanisms, particularly its impact on lipid regulation and foam cell formation.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reduced plaque and lipid deposition in atherosclerotic mice, improved lipid profiles (lowered total cholesterol and triglycerides, increased HDL), and decreased foam cell formation in human THP-1 monocytes. It acted via the TLR4/NF-κB pathway to suppress lipid-related proteins (ADRP, ALBP).
population_specificity: Atherosclerotic mice and LPS-stimulated human THP-1 monocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol reduces proinflammatory mediator production in lipopolysaccharide-stimulated BV2 microglia and primary brain microglia.
results_summary: Pycnogenol treatment was associated with dose-dependent reductions in nitric oxide, TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β, ICAM-1, and PLIN2 levels, as well as suppression of NF-κB and AP-1 activation, without affecting anti-inflammatory IL-10 production.
population_specificity: Mouse-derived BV2 microglia and primary brain microglia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Pycnogenol(®) combined with L-arginine in improving sperm quality and erectile function in infertile men with oligoasthenozoospermia and mild erectile dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in sperm concentration and erectile function scores (IIEF) after 4 months of treatment with Pycnogenol(®) and L-arginine. The combination therapy enhanced nitric oxide production and antioxidant effects, benefiting both sperm quality and erectile function.
population_specificity: Japanese men with oligoasthenoteratozoospermia syndrome (OAT) and mild erectile dysfunction.
effective_dosage: 60 mg Pycnogenol(®) and 690 mg L-arginine (daily frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol could attenuate ventilator-induced lung injury in rats by reducing inflammatory cytokines and inhibiting NF-κB activation.
results_summary: Pycnogenol pretreatment significantly reduced lung injury markers (wet/dry ratio, MPO activity, protein concentration) and inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β, MIP-2) in BALF, while improving lung histology and inhibiting NF-κB pathway activation.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to ventilator-induced lung injury.
effective_dosage: 30 mg/kg orally once, administered 2 days before injury induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol (PYC) could protect against rotenone-induced neurotoxicity in PC12 cells and explore the underlying mechanisms, particularly the NF-κB-iNOS signaling pathway.
results_summary: PYC treatment significantly increased cell viability and reduced apoptosis in rotenone-treated PC12 cells in a dose-dependent manner. It also downregulated NF-κB-iNOS signaling, suggesting a protective mechanism against neurotoxicity.
population_specificity: PC12 cells (a rat adrenal pheochromocytoma cell line used as a model for neuronal studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose-dependent effects observed but exact amounts not provided).
study_duration: Not specified (pretreatment and treatment durations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biological actions of Pycnogenol in treating metabolic syndrome and related disorders, including obesity, dyslipidaemia, diabetes, and hypertension.
results_summary: Pycnogenol demonstrated strong antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and vasodilator effects, improving blood glucose levels in diabetes, reducing blood pressure in hypertension, and enhancing lipid profile, renal, and endothelial functions in metabolic syndrome. Clinical studies supported its efficacy across multiple components of metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: People with metabolic syndrome, diabetes, mild to moderate hypertension, and related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer effects of Pycnogenol in MC-3 human mucoepidermoid carcinoma (MEC) cell line.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly decreased cell viability and induced caspase-independent apoptosis, including translocation of apoptosis-inducing factor into the nucleus and enhanced Bak protein stability.
population_specificity: MC-3 human oral mucoepidermoid carcinoma (MEC) cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the apoptotic effects of Pycnogenol and its constituents on human fibrosarcoma cells (HT1080) and compare its efficacy to its main components.
results_summary: Pycnogenol induced significant apoptotic cell death in HT1080 cells ex vivo, outperforming its individual constituents (catechin, epicatechin, taxifolin). Microarray analysis revealed gene expression changes linked to apoptotic pathways.
population_specificity: 10 healthy adults (6 females, 4 males, mean age 24.8 ± 6 years).
effective_dosage: Single dose of 300 mg Pycnogenol orally.
study_duration: Single administration, plasma samples taken 6 hours post-intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Prelox®R, containing Pycnogenol®, improves male fertility by enhancing sperm quality and e-NOS activity.
results_summary: Prelox®R significantly improved sperm volume, concentration, motility, vitality, morphology, and Fertility Index compared to placebo, with elevated e-NOS activity and no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: 50 subfertile men
study_duration: 1 month per treatment phase (with washout and crossover)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol, as an NF-κB inhibitor, could improve dysmenorrhea when used alongside a low-dose oral contraceptive.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced pain scores (from 9 to 2) and bleeding days compared to the contraceptive alone, with 27% of patients becoming pain-free. The difference between groups was statistically significant (P<0.0001).
population_specificity: 24 women with severe dysmenorrhea using a specific oral contraceptive (15 μg ethinyl estradiol + 60 mg gestodene).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Pycnogenol, alone and in combination with TTFCA, on atherosclerosis progression and oxidative stress in low-risk asymptomatic subjects with carotid or femoral stenosing plaques.
results_summary: Pycnogenol 100 mg/day significantly reduced plaque progression and cardiovascular events compared to controls, with the best results seen in combination with TTFCA. Oxidative stress was also reduced in all Pycnogenol groups, particularly in the combined treatment group.
population_specificity: Low-risk asymptomatic subjects aged 45-60 with carotid or femoral stenosing plaques (>50-60%) and no conventional risk factors.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/day or 100 mg/day of Pycnogenol, with some groups also receiving 100 mg/day of TTFCA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Pycnogenol® on HCV replication, including its potential synergistic effects with standard antiviral agents and its activity against resistant HCV mutants.
results_summary: Pycnogenol® demonstrated antiviral effects without cytotoxicity at doses up to 50 μg/mL, showed synergistic effects with interferon-alpha and ribavirin, and inhibited HCV replication in both wild-type and telaprevir-resistant replicon cells. It also reduced reactive oxygen species in HCV replicon cell lines and suppressed HCV replication in infected chimeric mice.
population_specificity: HCV replicon cells and HCV-infected chimeric mice.
interactions: Synergistic effects with interferon-alpha and ribavirin; additive effects with telaprevir.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pycnogenol's protective effects on oxidative stress, inflammation, and DNA damage in sepsis-induced rats.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA, GSH, SOD, GPx), lowered TNF-α levels, and decreased DNA damage in sepsis-induced rats. It also improved antioxidant status and DNA repair capacity.
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats with sepsis induced by cecal ligation and puncture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol could inhibit alveolar bone resorption and osteoclast differentiation in a rat model of periodontitis induced by P. gingivalis.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced alveolar bone resorption, inhibited P. gingivalis viability, prevented bacterial adhesion and invasion in epithelial cells, and suppressed osteoclast formation and survival.
population_specificity: Rats with induced periodontitis.
effective_dosage: 0.025% (w/w) in diet for in vivo; 1-100 µg/ml for in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol (PYC) could alleviate depression-like behavior in mice induced by chronic corticosterone (CORT) exposure.
results_summary: PYC supplementation significantly reduced immobility time in CORT-treated mice, suggesting it may mitigate CORT-induced stress through radical scavenging activity. The study indicates PYC has potential antidepressant-like effects in this model.
population_specificity: CORT-treated mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Pycnogenol supplementation improves psoriasis management outcomes and reduces the need for standard treatments.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation led to more pronounced reductions in affected skin areas, severity scores, and oxidative stress compared to standard management alone. It also improved skin moisture, quality of life, and reduced treatment time and costs.
population_specificity: Patients aged 30-45 with moderate/severe plaque psoriasis (PASI score ≥10 and 10-49% involved body area).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Pycnogenol on bone mineral density, trabecular microarchitecture, and bone metabolism in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: Pycnogenol (40 mg/kg) significantly improved bone mineral density, reduced bone resorption biomarkers, and restored trabecular microarchitecture in ovariectomized rats compared to untreated controls.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pycnogenol on airway inflammation using an allergic asthma model and RAW264.7 cells.
results_summary: Pycnogenol reduced inflammatory markers (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, IgE) and nitric oxide production, attenuated airway inflammation and mucus hypersecretion, and modulated the expression of iNOS, MMP-9, and HO-1 proteins.
population_specificity: OVA-induced allergic asthma model (in vivo) and LPS-stimulated RAW264.7 cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a low daily dosage of 50 mg Pycnogenol could effectively lower oxidative stress in healthy cigarette smokers.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced reactive oxygen metabolites (d-ROM values) by 25.3% after 2 weeks and maintained lower levels compared to placebo throughout the 8-week treatment. Biological antioxidant potential (BAP) also increased in the Pycnogenol group but dropped after cessation, while placebo values remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Healthy cigarette smokers
study_duration: 8 weeks of supplementation, followed by 2 weeks of cessation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the PKA-dependent inhibitory effect of Pycnogenol on lipolysis and its potential as a weight loss agent in obese mice and primary mouse adipocytes.
results_summary: Pycnogenol supplementation reduced body weight gain, visceral fat mass, serum and hepatic triglycerides, and total cholesterol while increasing HDL-cholesterol. It also promoted lipolysis in adipocytes via cAMP-dependent PKA activation, increasing HSL and reducing perilipin A levels.
population_specificity: Obese (ob/ob) mice and primary mouse adipocytes.
effective_dosage: 30 mg/kg in mice; 100 μg/mL in primary adipocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biological profile and clinical efficacy of Pycnogenol in treating chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) and related venous disorders.
results_summary: Pycnogenol demonstrated strong antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and vasodilator effects, reducing leg edema in CVI, lowering deep vein thrombosis incidence during long flights, and enhancing healing of venous ulcers and hemorrhoids. Clinical studies supported its efficacy in both oral and topical applications.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic venous insufficiency, deep vein thrombosis, post-thrombotic syndrome, long-haul flight-related leg edema, venous ulcers, and acute hemorrhoids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pycnogenol, among other phytonutrients, could extend the lifespan of male F1 hybrid mice.
results_summary: Pycnogenol, in combination with quercetin and taxifolin, increased body weight but did not significantly extend lifespan in the mice. The study suggests that isolated phytonutrients like Pycnogenol may not be effective longevity therapeutics.
population_specificity: Male F1 hybrid mice (12 months old at intervention start)
study_duration: Not specified (intervention began at 12 months of age)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the neuroprotective effects of Pycnogenol (PYC) after traumatic brain injury (TBI) and assess its therapeutic potential when administered at different post-injury time points.
results_summary: PYC treatment significantly reduced oxidative stress (TBARS) and protected synaptic proteins in both the cortex and hippocampus after TBI, demonstrating neuroprotective effects with a therapeutic window of at least 4 hours post-injury. The benefits were observed across all tested doses (1, 5, and 10 mg/kg) and treatment delays (15 min, 2 h, or 4 h post-injury).
population_specificity: Young adult male Sprague-Dawley rats with moderate/severe cortical contusion.
study_duration: Single dose, outcomes assessed at 96 hours post-TBI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective potential of Pycnogenol in a mouse model of Parkinson's disease, focusing on its effects on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegeneration.
results_summary: Pycnogenol significantly reduced MPTP-induced neuroinflammation, neurodegeneration, and behavioral impairments in mice, suggesting it protects dopaminergic neurons from toxicity. The study found marked reductions in oxidative stress, inflammatory markers, and improved motor coordination with Pycnogenol treatment.
population_specificity: MPTP-induced Parkinsonism mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Pycnogenol, alone or combined with TECA, on atherosclerosis progression and oxidative stress in low-risk asymptomatic subjects with non-stenosing plaques.
results_summary: Pycnogenol 100 mg/day reduced plaque progression and oxidative stress, with the best results seen when combined with TECA. The control and aspirin groups showed significantly higher plaque progression rates.
population_specificity: Low-risk asymptomatic subjects aged 45-60 with non-stenosing carotid or femoral plaques and no conventional risk factors.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/day or 100 mg/day of Pycnogenol; 100 mg/day of TECA in combination.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Pycnogenol and Vitamin E in treating Chemotherapy-Related Oral Mucositis (ChROM) in children.
results_summary: Pycnogenol showed significant improvement in oral mucositis compared to the control group, with results comparable to Vitamin E, but it was not effective for severe mucositis (grade 4).
population_specificity: Children aged 6-15 years with Chemotherapy-Related Oral Mucositis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the protective effects and mechanism of Pycnogenol (PYC) on hyperglycemia, inflammatory markers, and oxidative damage in a type I diabetes rat model.
results_summary: PYC significantly reduced hyperglycemia, inflammatory markers, and oxidative damage while improving insulin levels and hepatic glycogen in diabetic rats. It also showed protective effects on liver and pancreas histology.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats (type I diabetes model).
